dimred.ktn_analysis¶

Optimal Markovian coarse-graining given a community structure¶

This module provides functions to analyze and estimate coarse-grained continuous-time Markov chains given a partiioning \(\mathcal{C} = \{I, J, ...\}\) of the \(V\) nodes into \(N<V\) communities. Various formulations for the inter-community rates are implemented, including the local equilibrium approximation, Hummer-Szabo relation, and other routes to obtain the optimal coarse-grained Markov chain for a given community structure. [1]

[1]
  1. Kannan, D. J. Sharpe, T. D. Swinburne, D. J. Wales, “Dimensionality reduction of Markov chains from mean first passage times using graph transformation.” J. Chem. Phys. (2020)
class graph_tran.dimred.ktn_analysis.Analyze_KTN(path, K=None, pi=None, commpi=None, communities=None, commdata=None, temp=None, thresh=None)[source]¶

Analyze a kinetic transition network (KTN) with a specified community structure.

path¶

str or Path object – path to directory with all relevant files

K¶

array-like (nnodes, nnodes) – Rate matrix with elements \(K_{ij}\) corresponding to the i leftarrow j transition rate, and diagonal elements \(K_{ii} = -\sum_\gamma K_{\gamma i}\) such that the columns sum to zero.

pi¶

array-like (nnodes,) – Stationary distribution of nodes, \(\pi_i\), i.e. vector of equilibrium occupation probabilities.

commpi¶

array-like (ncomms,) – Stationary distribution of communities, \(\Pi_J = \sum_{j \in J} \pi_j\).

communities¶

dict – dictionary mapping community IDs (1-indexed) to node IDs (1-indexed).

commdata¶

str – Filename, located in directory specified by path, of a single-column file where each line contains the community ID (0-indexed) of the node specified by the line number in the file

Note

Either communities or commdata must be specified.

calculate_eigenfunction_error(m, K, R)[source]¶

Calculate the \(i^{\rm th}\) eigenvector approximation error for \(i \in {1, 2, ... m}\) of a coarse-grained rate matrix R by comparing its eigenvector to the correspcorresponding eigenvector of the full matrix.

construct_coarse_rate_matrix_Hummer_Szabo(temp=None)[source]¶

Calculate the optimal coarse-grained rate matrix using the Hummer-Szabo relation, aka Eqn. (12) in Hummer & Szabo J. Phys. Chem. B. (2015).

construct_coarse_rate_matrix_KKRA(mfpt=None, GT=False, temp=None, **kwargs)[source]¶

Calculate optimal coarse-grained rate matrix using Eqn. (79) of Kells et al. J. Chem. Phys. (2020), aka the KKRA expression in Eqn. (10) of Kannan et al. J. Chem. Phys. (2020).

Parameters:
  • mfpt ((nnodes, nnodes)) – Matrix of inter-microstate MFPTs between all pairs of nodes. Defaults to None.
  • GT (bool) – If True, matrix of inter-microstate MFPTs is computed with GT using the graph_tran.fpt_stats module. Kwargs can then be specified for GT (such as the pool_size for parallelization). Defaults to False.
construct_coarse_rate_matrix_LEA(temp=None)[source]¶

Calculate the coarse-grained rate matrix obtained using the local equilibrium approximation (LEA).

construct_coarse_rate_matrix_from_MFPTs(temp=None)[source]¶

Calculate a rate matrix using MFPTs between communities. Note that the true-intercommunity MFPTs cannot be used to construct a reduced Markov chain that satisfies detailed balance.

get_comm_stat_probs(logpi, log=True)[source]¶

Calculate the community stationary probabilities by summing over the stationary probabilities of the nodes in each community.

Parameters:logpi (list (nnodes,)) – log stationary probabilities of node in original Markov chain
Returns:
  • commpi (list (ncomms,)) – stationary probabilities of communities in coarse coarse_network
  • TODO (account for unconnected minima (set their occupation probs to 0))
get_free_energies_from_rates(R, thresh, temp, kB=1.0, planck=1.0)[source]¶

Estimate free energies of all macrostates and transition states between macrostates from an arbitrary rate matrix R. Write out a min.data and ts.data file for coarse-grained network.

TODO: Get largest connected component of coarse-grained rate matrix.

Warning

It is better to write the coarse-grained matrix to a rate_matrix.dat file specifying all of the entries of the matrix in dense format, and then use this file as input to PATHSAMPLE as opposed to attepting to write out min.data or ts.data files representing the coarse-grained network.

get_intercommunity_MFPTs_linear_solve()[source]¶

Calculate the true MFPTs between communities by inverting the non-absorbing rate matrix. Equivalent to Eqn. (14) in Swinbourne & Wales JCTC (2020).

get_intercommunity_weighted_MFPTs(pi, commpi, mfpt)[source]¶

Comppute the matrix \(\textbf{t}_{\rm C}\) of appropriately weighted inter-community MFPTs, as defined in Eq. (18) in Kannan et al. J. Chem. Phys. (2020).

get_intermicrostate_mfpts_fundamental_matrix()[source]¶

Calculate the matrix of inter-microstate MFPTs between all pairs of nodes using Eq. (6) of Kannan et al. J. Chem. Phys. (2020).

get_intermicrostate_mfpts_linear_solve()[source]¶

Calculate the matrix of inter-microstate MFPTs between all pairs of nodes by solving a system of linear equations given by Eq.(8) of Kannan et al. J. Chem. Phys. (2020).

get_thetaIJ(pi, commpi, mfpt)[source]¶

Compute the matrix with elements \(\theta_{IJ}\) as defined in Eq. (16) in Kannan et al. J. Chem. Phys. (2020).

get_timescale_error(m, K, R)[source]¶

Calculate the ith timescale error for i in {1,2,…m} of a coarse-grained rate matrix R compared to the full matrix K.

Parameters:
  • m (int) – Number of dominant eigenvalues (m < N)
  • K (np.ndarray[float] (V, V)) – Rate matrix for full network
  • R (np.ndarray[float] (N, N)) – Coarse-grained rate matrix
Returns:

timescale_errors – Errors for m-1 slowest timescales
Return type:

np.ndarray[float] (m-1,)
graph_tran.dimred.ktn_analysis.calc_eigenvectors(K, k, which_eig='SM', norm=False)[source]¶

Calculate k dominant eigenvectors and eigenvalues of sparse matrix using the implictly restarted Arnoldi method.

graph_tran.dimred.ktn_analysis.calculate_spectral_error(m, Rs, labels)[source]¶

Calculate spectral error, where m is the number of dominant eigenvalues in both the reduced and original transition networks, as a function of lag time for various coarse grained rate-matrices specified in the array Rs. Plots the decay.

graph_tran.dimred.ktn_analysis.check_detailed_balance(pi, K)[source]¶

Check if Markov chain satisfies detailed balance condition, \(k_{ij} \pi_j = k_{ji} \pi_i\) for all \(i,j\).

Parameters:
  • pi (array-like (nnodes,) or (ncomms,)) – stationary probabilities
  • K (array-like (nnodes, nnodes) or (ncomms, ncomms)) – transition rate matrix
graph_tran.dimred.ktn_analysis.construct_transition_matrix(K, tau_lag)[source]¶

Return column-stochastic transition matrix \(\textbf{T} = \rm{exp}(\textbf{K}\tau)\) where \(\tau\) is the lag time tau_lag.

graph_tran.dimred.ktn_analysis.get_timescales(K, m, tau_lag)[source]¶

Return characteristic timescales obtained from the m dominant eigenvalues of the transition matrix constructed from K at lag time tau_lag.

graph_tran.dimred.ktn_analysis.read_communities(commdat)[source]¶

Read in a single column file called communities.dat where each line is the community ID (zero-indexed) of the minima given by the line number.

Parameters:commdat (dat file) – single-column file containing community IDs of each minimum
Returns:communities – mapping from community ID (1-indexed) to minima ID (1-indexed)
Return type:dict
graph_tran.dimred.ktn_analysis.read_ktn_info(self, suffix, log=False)[source]¶

Read in input files stat_prob_{suffix}.dat, ts_weights_{suffix}.dat, and ts_conns_{suffix}.dat describing the stationary probabilities and connectivity of the nodes in the Markov chain to be analyzed. Files must be located in the directory specified by self.path.
